text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single rectangular miniature framed by a full border at the foot of the page, clearly separated from any surrounding text; no integration of text and image; image occupies full width within its border with a narrow margin

color_scheme.color_usage: The deep ultramarine background is punched with burnished gold to denote a regal interior; gold leaf highlights on robes and regalia signify divine favor and royal authority; vermillion drapery behind the altar provides vibrant contrast; lead-white is used for floor tiles and robes’ highlights; brown-black ink outlines define figures with clarity; pigments remain largely intact with minimal darkening.

features: Central ritual act emphasized by grouping figures around the bishop and kneeling monarch
Hierarchical scaling elevates the bishop and kneeling figure above attendant ranks
Balanced arrangement: crown-bearers on left counterbalanced by altar structure on right
Diagonal visual line from crown at left through kneeling figure to bishop

decorative_elements: Full red and gold border with geometric pattern and fleuron corner ornaments
Gilded punched gold motif on blue background
Diapered tile floor pattern in alternating red and white
Miniature Gothic architectural framing around the altar

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work with bold outer contours and finer internal details in brown-black ink
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal hatching in drapery folds supplemented by white lead highlights for volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Shallow pictorial space achieved through overlapping figures and tiled floor; no true linear perspective, characteristic of Gothic illumination

content_theme.scene_description: This full-page miniature depicts the coronation Mass of a French king. At center, the newly anointed monarch kneels before a bishop wearing a richly decorated mitre and holding both a gilded chalice and a host wafer. The king wears a blue robe strewn with gold fleur-de-lis, his hands raised in reverence. To the left, six attendants in fleur-de-lis patterned garments stand behind a youth presenting a gold crown on a velvet cushion; another holds a ceremonial sword with gilt hilt. The tiled floor beneath them is laid in red and white lozenges, creating a shallow stage. At right, a small altar draped in red cloth with a carved reredos depicting saints anchors the composition. All figures are rendered against a dense ultramarine background punched with gold dots. The arrangement emphasizes the central sacramental moment: the convergence of secular regalia and ecclesiastical authority. Attendants’ postures and glances guide the viewer’s eye from the crown-bearers through the kneeling figure to the bishop, reinforcing the ritual’s solemn progression. No marginal scenes or text intrude on the frame, marking this as a standalone depiction of royal investiture.

religious: bishop wearing mitre holding chalice and host
secular: attendant nobility in fleur-de-lis garments holding crown

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniformly prepared, smooth surface; evidence of professional scraping and pumicing; quaternion gathering with consistent margins
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments remain vivid with minimal oxidation; slight flaking of vermillion at edges; gold leaf intact albeit with tiny fissures; no major staining or warping
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf creating subtle relief
Fine underdrawing visible under UV examination
Precisely ruled grid for floor pattern alignment

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Royal chapel clergy and court officials

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illumination appears to originate from a mid-14th-century French court workshop, likely commissioned to commemorate the coronation of a Capetian monarch. The lavish ultramarine and gold palette, together with the fleur-de-lis motif, underscores the political alliance between the crown and the Church. The image’s separation from text suggests its inclusion in a ceremonial manual or secular chronicle rather than a devotional codex. Stylistically, the miniaturist employs a hierarchical composition and delicate quill outlining typical of Parisian ateliers. The use of punched gold in the background and raised gesso underlayer reflects advanced technical practices aimed at creating a jewel-like effect, paralleling works such as the Grandes Chroniques de France. Iconographically, the juxtaposition of regalia bearers and the Eucharistic action signals an ideological message: royal authority is both divinely sanctioned and sacramentally validated. This reinforces the medieval notion of the king as God’s anointed instrument on earth. Comparatively, the image shares formal affinities with the Coronation scenes in the Psalter of Saint Louis, yet innovates by integrating the Mass into the visual program, thus blending liturgical and political narratives in a single frame. The result is a sophisticated fusion of tradition and innovation, marking a high point of French Gothic illumination.
